turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: Come in, come in, siddown over there. Coffee?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: What's involved, aside from putting up the money? What're you looking for the partner to do?

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: Do? Hell, nothing. Well, you'll want to keep tabs on your investment, of course, but I'm looking for a silent partner. I've done the research, I've contacted the vendors, the deal is set. I'm just looking for venture capital, friend. Disappear if you want, check in whenever you like--I want the dough; I don't take attendance.

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: Fifty-fifty, straight down the line. You and me. Finance and expertise. So--you've got the dough then, do ya?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I'll have it in a week.

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: Well, I'll be damned. The barber! And I thought this trip was a bust. Well...

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: ...it just goes to show, when one door slams shut, another one opens. Here's to ya, uh...

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: ...Usually we do this kind of thing with a bank draft. But cash--that's fine--it's all the same in the end-- dough's dough, huh?

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: I got the paperwork here. Partnership papers here, they reflect our agreement: fifty-fifty on the net, I supply professional services, you supply the capital. I'll give you a receipt on the dough there, huh?

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: Pretty straightforward, but I don't know if you wanna show this stuff to a lawyer--

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: Yeah, screw 'em, huh? Pay 'em to tangle it up and then you pay 'em to untangle it, what's the point?

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: ...Just a second here, I'll give you a receipt on the, uh... Whoa, Nellie... Oh, by the way, we didn't talk about this, I, uh, I think I'm gonna call the place Tolliver's, after me, you know, I didn't think you were much interested in, uh--

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: ...Yeah, that's it. As per our discussion.

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: Well, there it is. Writ large in legal escriture, next step is--

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: ...You're not gonna screw me on this?

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: *Screw* you--Jesus! Take it to a lawyer! No, I insist! This is *dry* cleaning, this is not some fly-by- night thing here! I must say, I've been an entrepreneur for thirteen years and I've never--

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: And I've never been asked--Look, you want the dough back? You know who I am! You--

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: ...That's quite a wife you got there.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: Couldn't be better. These're boom times in retailing. We're opening another store, Big Dave's Annex, there on Garson. This is strictly haberdashery--casual wear, pyjamas, ladies' foundations and undergarments. Matter of fact, I'm thinking of making Doris the comptroller. How're things at the, uh, the barbershop?

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: ...Fine. Fine. Well, you might want to drop by the Annex when we open, update your suit--'course, you're in the smock all day.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: ...Say, where do you get those things anyway?

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: Hell, I, I'm not proud of it. But, uh, that's not the worst of it. I got a note. A blackmail note. You know, come across or everybody knows.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: Well, you know what that would do to me.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I guess it would be pretty awkward.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: Awkward?! Ann'd throw me out on my keister! Hell, it's her family's store--*her* store. I serve at the indulgence of the goddamn ownership, Ed.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: I only work here! And the lady's husband would know... Oh, Jesus.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: How much to they want, Dave?

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: $10,000! I don't know what to do, Ed. I don't know what I *can* do. Even though I know who the sonofabitch is.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: The sonofabitch. The blackmailer. It's, uh, it's no one you know. It's a businessman from Sacramento. A goddamn pansy, Ed. He tried to rope me into some crackpot scheme; I heard him out and then told him to go to hell. And the very next day, the very next day, Ed, I get blackmailed for the same amount.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Would he... it sounds pretty obvious.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: Well, I guess he don't care that it's obvious.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Mm. How, uh... how did he know that--

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: He's staying at the hotel I've gone to with, uh, with the lady in question. Must've seen us.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: ...Why don't you just pay him, Dave?

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: That's my capitalization on the Annex! *My* operation, Ed! Christ almighty. That's what I was just talking to Doris about, a way of getting the money from the store that we could hide from Ann.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: Embezzling, Ed. From my own goddamn wife!

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: I'm at Nirdlinger's. Let yourself in.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: ...It ruined me. This money. No annex. I'm all shot to hell.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: I'd understand if you'd walked in here. Socked me in the nose. Whatever. I deserved it.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: I'm not proud of what I did. But *you*.

turns.speaker: DIEDRICKSON
turns.text: You sure you don't want something stiffer?

turns.speaker: DIEDRICKSON
turns.text: ...Doesn't become a matter of public record unless there's foul play. However. I don't believe I'm *prohibited* from telling you this. I guess I'm not obliged to tell you, either. I don't exactly know.  But if *I* were the man, I'd want to be told.

turns.speaker: DIEDRICKSON
turns.text: ...Hell, I hope I've done the right thing.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: My wife and I had not... performed the sex act in many years.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: ...My first instinct was, no, no, the whole idea was nuts. But maybe that was the instinct that kept me locked up in the barbershop, nose against the exit, afraid to try turning the knob. What if I could get the money?

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: Me? Us! The party at Nirdlinger's--I told you last week, for the Christmas Push.

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: Come on, get ready. It's important.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Nah, go ahead. I'm not big on parties.

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: ...Money problems. He's thinking about canceling the Annex.

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: Life is so goddamn wonderful, you almost won't believe it.

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: It's just a goddamn bowl of cherries, I'm sure.

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: I don't know what's going on. I--

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: ...I don't know what happened to Big Dave. I know some of it. Irregularities in my books, they said. Can I explain it.

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: I helped him cook the books, Ed. I did do that.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: You don't have to tell them anything. We're getting you a lawyer.

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: I know all about that. But I don't know how much to tell them.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Don't tell 'em anything. We're getting you Freddy Riedenschneider.

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: Should I... should I tell you why?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: You don't have to tell me anything.

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: ...My books used to be perfect. Anyone could open them up, make sense of the whole goddamn store.

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: I knew we'd pay for it.

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: Nah, don't say anything. I'm alright.

turns.speaker: RIEDENSCHNEIDER
turns.text: Look, I don't wanna waste your time so I'll eat while we talk. Ya mind? *You* don't mind. So while I'm in town I'll be staying at the Hotel Metropole, the Turandot Suite. Yeah, it's goofy, the suites're named after operas; room's OK though, I poked around. I'm having 'em hold it for me on account of I'll be back and forth. In addition to my retainer, you're paying hotel, living expenses, secretarial, private eye if we need to make inquiries, headshrinker should we go that way. We'll talk about appeals if, as and when. For right now, has she confessed?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: No. Of course not. She didn't do it.

turns.speaker: RIEDENSCHNEIDER
turns.text: Good! That helps. Not that she didn't do it, that she didn't confess. Of course, there's ways to deal with a confession, but that's good!--one less thing to think about. Now. Interview. I'm seeing her tomorrow. You should be there. Three o'clock. One more thing: you keep your mouth shut. I get the lay of the land, I tell *you* what to say. No talking out of school. What's out of school? Everything's out of school. I do the talking; you keep your trap shut. I'm an attorney, you're a barber; you don't know anything. Understood?

turns.speaker: RIEDENSCHNEIDER
turns.text: Good! Any questions give me a ring-- Turandot suite; if I'm out leave a message. You sure you don't want anything? No?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I knew about it. Big Dave told me about it, and the spot he was putting himself in by getting the money.

turns.speaker: RIEDENSCHNEIDER
turns.text: Terrific. Your husband backs you up. That's terrific.

turns.speaker: RIEDENSCHNEIDER
turns.text: ...You've gotta give me something to work with. Freddy Riedenschneider is good, but he's not a magician. He can't just wave his little wand in the air and make a plausible defense materialize. Look. Look at what the other side is gonna run at us. They got the company books, prepared by you--*cooked* by you--that's Motive. They got a murder scene *you* had access to. That's Opportunity. They got that little trimmer thing he was stabbed in the throat with--a *dame's* weapon--

turns.speaker: RIEDENSCHNEIDER
turns.text: --don't interrupt me--that's Means. They got a fine upstanding pillar of the business community as a victim, and then they got *you*, a disgruntled number-juggling underling who on the day in question was drunk as a skunk and whose alibi for the time in question is being passed out at home, alone.

turns.speaker: RIEDENSCHNEIDER
turns.text: OK, we forget the blackmail. *You* killed him. How come?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: He and Doris... were having an affair.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I... just knew. A husband knows.

turns.speaker: RIEDENSCHNEIDER
turns.text: Will anyone else say they knew?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I don't know. I don't think so.

turns.speaker: RIEDENSCHNEIDER
turns.text: How did you get into the store?

turns.speaker: RIEDENSCHNEIDER
turns.text: Will anyone say they saw you there? On your way there? In there? On your was back?

turns.speaker: RIEDENSCHNEIDER
turns.text: Will anyone corroborate and goddamn part of your story at all?

turns.speaker: RIEDENSCHNEIDER
turns.text: Look, chum, this is a guy, from what I understand, told everybody he was a war hero, right? Island hopping, practically liberated the Pacific all by himself with a knife in one hand and a gun in the other and twenty yards of Jap guts between his teeth.

turns.speaker: RIEDENSCHNEIDER
turns.text: And now it turns out this dope spent the war sitting on his ass in some boatyard in San Diego. You asked for blackmail, let me give you blackmail: Mr Hale-Fellow-Well-Met, about to open his own business here, has been lying to everybody in this town for the last four years, probably including half the people sitting on that jury. Well, it finally caught up with him--these dopes, it always does; someone threatened to spill it. Somebody knew his dirty little secret, just like your wife says. They called, they demanded money...

turns.speaker: RIEDENSCHNEIDER
turns.text: ...Did Big Dave mention that it was something about his war service? I don't know, I wasn't there, *you'll* have to tell *us*. Maybe he specified, maybe he didn't; I'm not putting words in your mouth; the point is that this liar, this cynical manipulator, this man who through his lies sneered and belittled the sacrifice and heroism of all our boys who *did* serve and bleed and puke and die on foreign shores, and who made a fool out of this entire town, turns to *you* to help him out of his jam. Fat-assed sonofabitch!

turns.speaker: RIEDENSCHNEIDER
turns.text: Who? *Who?!* I don't know who! But the point is that if Mr Prosecutor over there had devoted half the time he's spent persecuting *this* woman to even the most cursory investigation of this schmoe's past, then we might *know* who! But we can't *know* what really happened! Because of Fritz, or Werner, or whatever the hell his name is! And because Me Prosecutor is *also* a lazy fat-assed sonofabitch who decided it's easier to victimize your wife! Because it's easier *not* to look! Because the more you look, the less you know! But the beauty of it is, we don't *gotta* know! We just gotta show that, goddamnit, *they* don't know. Reasonable doubt. Science. The atom. *You* explain it to me. Go ahead. Try.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I tried to tell him the whole story, but Riedenschneider stopped me. He said the story made his head hurt, and anyway he didn't see any way of using it without putting me on the hot seat for the murder of Big Dave...

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: ...I gotta hand it to him, he tossed a lot of sand in their eyes. He talked about how I'd lost my place in the universe...

turns.speaker: RIEDENSCHNEIDER
turns.text: ...a puny player on the great world's stage...

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: ...how I was too ordinary to be the criminal mastermind the D.A. made me out to be, how there was some greater scheme at work that the state had yet to unravel, and he threw in some of the old truth stuff he hadn't had a chance to trot out for Doris...

turns.speaker: RIEDENSCHNEIDER
turns.text: ...who among us is in a position to say...

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: ...He told them to look at me--look at me close. That the closer they looked the less sense it would all make, that I wasn't the kind of guy to kill a guy, that I was the barber, for Christ's sake...

turns.speaker: RIEDENSCHNEIDER
turns.text: ...and inflame the passions of these twelve fine men and women...

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: ...Well, he got his mistrial, but the well had run dry. There was nothing left to mortgage; Riedenschneider went home and the court appointed Lloyd Garroway...

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Thanks. Thanks for seeing me, at home.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Well, of course, I, uh, it's out of my league, criminal stuff. I do, uh, probate, real estate, title search, uh... I'd be absolutely worthless, something like this. Absolutely worthless.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: 'Scuse me, just finished dinner. Um. Frankly, Doris'd be better off with the county defender.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Bert's OK, sure, he's a good man. I won't kid you though, Ed, nobody around here has any experience with this kind of, er... And I hear they're bringing a prosecutor up from Sacramento. Capital offense. Taking it seriously... Hmm...

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Well, there's Lloyd Garroway in San Francisco. Probity--you know, no one ever said anything iffy about Lloyd Garroway. Conservative. Jury might like that. Might like that here.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Uh-huh. Is he the best then, for, uh...

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Well, the best, the money-is-no-object best, for a criminal case, any lawyer would tell you Freddy Riedenschneider. Out of Sacramento. 'Course, I don't know how you're fixed for money.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I'm so damn sorry about your loss. Terrible thing. Just damn terrible.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Birdy's in the parlor--I'm on long distance here.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: Haven't I seen you up in ladies' wear?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I don't work here. My wife does.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: Check out the rack on that broad in the angora.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
turns.text: Oh, no. That was written by Mr Ludwig van Beethoven.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
turns.text: He wrote some beautiful piano sonatas.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: That was something. I'm Ed Crane.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
turns.text: I know who you are, Mr Crane.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
turns.text: ...I'm Rachel Abundas. Everyone calls me Birdy.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Says here that the Russians exploded n A-bomb and there's not a damn thing we can do about it.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Now, being a barber is a lot like being a barman or a soda-jerk; there's not much to it once you've learned the basic moves. For the kids there's the Butch, or the Heinie...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: ...so you tie your own flies, Ed. I mean, if you're really serious. You tie your own flies, you do a--I know it's matickless, I know, people say, hey, you can buy flies at the store-- but you can buy your fish at the store, Ed, you see what I'm saying?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: The point is there's a certain art to the process. The point is not merely to provide, and let me point out, these fish are not as dumb as you might think.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Sportsmanship! That's my point. June fly, Ed? Mosquito? Which of these? Well, what fish do you seek?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Sure, go to the store. Go there, describe to the man where you will be fishing, and for what, and the weather conditions, sun, no sun, whatnot, and so forth, and then you might as well have the man go ahead and sell you the goddamn FISH, Ed...

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I don't know... How it keeps on coming. It just keeps growing.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: No, I mean it's growing, it's part of us. And we cut it off. And throw it away.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Come on, Eddie, you're gonna scare the kid.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: ...I'm gonna take his hair and throw it out in the dirt.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I'm gonna mingle it with common house dirt.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What the hell are you talking about?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Damn, I got a headache to beat the band.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: This is what family is for, Ed! This is when ya come together!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Close ranks! Goddamnit! Those sons of bitches!

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Frank, uh, you know I'll try to contribute, but, uh--Freddy Riedenschneider--

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I don't care what it costs! This is when ya come together!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: They're just people like you and me, Ed. Remember that.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Just people. They gotta put up the big front so that people will trust them with their money. This is why the big lobby, Ed. But they put their pants on one leg at a time. Just like you and me.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: They too use the toilet, Ed. In spite of appearances. And their money will be secured by the barbershop. A rock. A *rock*, the barbershop. I mean, how long has *this* place been here?

turns.speaker: KREBS
turns.text: They sent us to tell ya. We pulled the detail.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: You also have an interest in the securing property?

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Barber, right? I'm Freddy Riedenschneider. Hungry? They tell me the chow's OK here. I made some inquiries.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: My name is Diedrickson. County medical examiner.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Well, have you ever considered tar Macadam? People think it's just for public works and commercial purposes, roads, parking lots, so forth...

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: OK, boys, which of you gets the privilege?

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Oh, happy days! I wish I was doing well enough to turn away business! More power to ya, brother! The public be damned!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Hey, what's your problem, friend? This is a business establishment with posted hours--

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Could you come with me please?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No, he's family, he's my brother-in- law.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Ah-hah. It would be best if he waited here.

turns.speaker: KREBS
turns.text: ...Look, pal, it's a tough break, but, uh... well damnit, your wife's been pinched.

turns.speaker: PERSKY
turns.text: They sent us to tell ya.

turns.speaker: PERSKY
turns.text: Yeah, uh, they brung her to the county jail, uh...

turns.speaker: PERSKY
turns.text: Well, embezzlement. And homicide. A guy named David Brewster. He's, uh... He's the decedent.

turns.speaker: KREBS
turns.text: Visiting ends at five. Too late today. You can see her tomorrow.

turns.speaker: PERSKY
turns.text: Sorry, pal. They sent us to tell ya.

turns.speaker: PERSKY
turns.text: Are you awake?... Is he awake?

turns.speaker: KREBS
turns.text: Crane? We have to tell you, as soon as you're conscious--is he conscious?

turns.speaker: PERSKY
turns.text: As soon as the doctor lets us, we gotta move you. Does he understand that? We're supposed to tell him. Are you conscious?

turns.speaker: KREBS
turns.text: You'll go to the prison hospital.

turns.speaker: KREBS
turns.text: What'd he say? Does he understand?

turns.speaker: PERSKY
turns.text: He said OK. Is that what he said?

turns.speaker: BAILEY
turns.text: Uh, Vince.  Sorry.  This won't wait.

turns.speaker: BAILEY
turns.text: There are a couple of kids who were lost yesterday near the site of the murder.  Claimed they saw a monster. They're pretty determined to tell you their story.  You want to see them?

turns.speaker: BAILEY
turns.text: Manual overrides aren't working.  I'm getting nothing, Lieutenant.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: There's some kind of animal loose in the museum.  Pendergast's alone.  He needs help.  I want volunteers to go with me.

turns.speaker: CUTHBERT
turns.text: Beauregard!  You scared me half to death.

turns.speaker: CUTHBERT
turns.text: Doesn't look like it.  We're damned lucky.  This statue is priceless.

turns.speaker: BEAUREGARD
turns.text: Looks like the curse is still at work.

turns.speaker: CUTHBERT
turns.text: The claws are sharp... I must have cut myself.  Better move these crates to the secure storage area where they'll be safe.

turns.speaker: BEAUREGARD
turns.text: Don't know if it'll do any good, Mr. Cuthbert.

turns.speaker: BEAUREGARD
turns.text: No one broke into this room, sir. Someone broke out.  That lock was torn off from the <u>inside</u>.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: We all love the museum.  I come here myself with my kids.  We're trying to work with you.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: I'm telling you, something's wrong. I still haven't heard from Pendergast.  I think you should call it off.

turns.speaker: CUTHBERT
turns.text: It's too late now.  Guests are arriving.  The Mayor's car is pulling up.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: I'll go down and speak to him.

turns.speaker: CUTHBERT
turns.text: You haven't got the authority.  Only Pendergast can pull the plug.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Pendergast may be in trouble.  Don't you understand?  He still hasn't come back.  It's been over three hours --

turns.speaker: CUTHBERT
turns.text: He'll be back.  Relax.  We're in good shape.  Your security is air tight. There've been no more incidents, nothing suspicious.  There's no reason to call off the opening now.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Get his gun and his walkie talkie, Jonathan.  Move.

turns.speaker: CUTHBERT
turns.text: My office is on the third floor! There's a walk-in safe and a portable phone!  We can lock ourselves in the safe and call for help!

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: I have to help Pendergast.  Kawakita and Jonathan stay with me.  The rest of you can go with Cuthbert!

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: I had no idea the Museum had a complete collection of Piranesi's Forum sketches.

turns.speaker: CUTHBERT
turns.text: If you like them, they're for sale. Another day like yesterday and half the collection will be on the block.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: I've read about the Museum's financial troubles.

turns.speaker: CUTHBERT
turns.text: We've been operating in the red for years.  That was the whole idea behind the Superstition Exhibit.  It was designed to pull people in. We've spent every penny we have on advance publicity, betting everything on the opening's success. If we postpone at the last minute... No.  I don't want to think about that.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: If the party goes forward, and that's a big if... I've arranged for a large police presence.

turns.speaker: CUTHBERT
turns.text: Do they have to wear uniforms?

turns.speaker: CUTHBERT
turns.text: I don't want to scare people.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: I understand.  But Mr. Cuthbert, we've got bigger problems.  Depending on what we find today, we may have to shut you down.

turns.speaker: CUTHBERT
turns.text: I got it after I was mugged in the subway last spring.

turns.speaker: CUTHBERT
turns.text: I'll do it.  Just let me find my portable phone.
